results.title: Queen of the border
results.brief_description: A film on the border town of Hawick, at work and at play. Hawick’s fame rests not only o its ancient battle honours, commemorated for three days every year, but on the sweaters which its craftsmen have knitted for generations, and which the film shows in process of manufacture.

results.title: Queen of flowers
results.creator_credit: New Zealand National Film Unit, Geoffrey Scott, Oxley Hughan and John Cooper
results.brief_description: The rose has been the world’s favourite flower for over 4,000 years. Becasue of the most favourable climate in new Zealand, roses flourish, and New Zealanders are amongst the world’s keenest growers of this beautiful flower.

results.title: Queen Margot = La Reine Margot
results.creator_credit: Claude Berri, Renn Productions, France Z Cinema, D.A. Films and Patrice Chereau
results.brief_description: A lavish production set in France in 1572 when French Catholic and Protestants were at war. Catherine de Medici, mother of King Charles IX, arranges a political marriage between her daughter Margot and the French Protestant King of Navarre, Henri. Thousands of Protestant flock to Paris for the wedding and are butchered in the infamous St. Bartholmew massacre. Margot takes a Protestant lover, La Mole, but the repercussions of the massacre are destined to tear them apart. Isabelle Adjani is excellent as the sensuous, strong-willed Margot while Daniel Auteil is La Mole. Italian actress Virna Lisa plays the evil Catherine de Medici. Spoken in French and subtitled in English.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Claude Berri, Renn Productions, France Z Cinema, D.A. Films and Patrice Chereau

results.title: Queen Kelly
results.creator_credit: Gloria Swanson, Gloria Swanson Pictures and Erich Von Stroheim
results.brief_description: In this melodrama, Gloria Swanson plays Patricia Kelly, a naive and innocent convent girl, who catches the eye of the decadent Prince of a small European country, when her underpants accidentally fall down. He embarks on a scandalous affair with her but when the Prince’s fiancee, mad Queen Regina (Seena Owen) learns of the affair she is enraged and intervenes. In one, now famous scene, she drives Patricia from the Palace, brandishing a whip. Although Stroheim was fired by Swanson after shooting only a third of the film, the final result reflects his fascination with perversion, decadent living and forbidden love between social classes.

results.title: Queen Kat, Carmel & St Jude: Parts 3-4: Spring-Summer
results.creator_credit: Chris Warner, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Film Victoria, ABC-TV (Australia), Trout Films and Moira Moss
results.brief_description: Based on Maureen McCarthy’s popular novel “Queen Kat, Carmel & St Jude get a life”, this made for television mini-series will strike a chord with anyone who has made the transition from country to city, high school to university, or just struggling to find themselves. There are four episodes in the series - each from the perspective of one of the three housemates - the final episode draws together the threads of the burgeoning friendship. “Spring: Chapter three: Kat.” Kat is having problems with boyfriend Dion (Simon Bossell) after she sits for a series of nude photographs. Things escalate when Dion plants drugs on Kat and she is arrested by the police and taken in for questioning. She is faced with the moral dilemma of deciding between co-operating with the police and giving Dion up, or remaining quiet, thus jeopardising her law career. Carmel is still pining over Anton but her emotions are placed on hold when she returns home to her terminally ill mother. Her absence gives Kat and Jude time to bond. Are the housemates becoming friends? “Winter: Chapter four: Manella.” Everyone gathers at Mrs McCaffrey’s funeral and Carmel has to reach a decision about her future; personal dreams or family loyalty, and whether she loves unfaithful Anton. Her family, along with some help from Kat, struggles to save the farm from being taken over. Results are in and there is a bonfire party to celebrate. Written by Meaghan Smith.

results.title: Queen Kat, Carmel & St Jude. Parts 1-2: Autumn-Winter
results.creator_credit: Chris Warner, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Film Victoria, ABC-TV (Australia), Trout Films and Moira Moss
results.brief_description: Based on Maureen McCarthy’s popular novel “Queen Kat, Carmel & St Jude get a life”, this made for television mini-series will strike a chord with anyone who has made the transition from country to city, high school to university, or just struggling to find themselves. There are four episodes in the series - each from the perspective of one of the three housemates - the final episode draws the threads together of the burgeoning friendship. “Autumn: Chapter one: Carmel.” Carmel McCaffrey (Alicia Gardiner), gifted singer, pianist and only daughter in a sheep farming family is facing resistance from her mother who is reluctant for her to go to university, citing she is a country girl like her mother and the family cannot afford for her to go: only her brother Vince (Ben Mendelsohn) seems to be on her side. Carmel makes it to Melbourne however and moves in with law student “Princess” Kat (Elissa Elliot), and down to earth Jude (Ingrid Ruz). Carmel struggles with her financial situation, has a palpably uncomfortable presentation, and after questioning her choice of career, drops out and returns briefly to Manella. She also meets Anton (Justin Smith). “Winter: Chapter two: Jude.” Med student Jude is following in the professional and political path of her deceased father Carlos who died as a political prisoner in Chile, much to the chagrin of her mother. Jude is plagued by memories she cannot suppress of her absent father and seeks solace in the arms of the married Eduardo. Carmel reluctantly makes her first public appearance, no thanks to a surprise visit by her mother. Written by Meaghan Smith.

results.title: Queen Elizabeth II in Pakistan
results.brief_description: H.M. the Queen’s tour of Pakistan, 1961. Her Majesty’s welcome by President Ayub Khan preceded a round of engagements during which she saw the country’s transitions as well as present-day developments. These included a visit to the great Warsak Dam; the gift of sheep by local leaders at the Khyber Pass; the Lahore Horse Show; the bare acres on which Islamabad, the new capital, will be built; a torchlight tattoo; the Badshahi mosque; and the lovely Shalimar and Gulistan-I-Fatima Gardens in Lahore, in which Pakistan’s National costumes and folk-dancing were displayed. The worlds largest jute mill, a trip by river boat, and a final tribute of rose petals.

results.title: Queen Elizabeth 2 sails around New Zealand and Australia
results.brief_description: Doug Jones sets sail with the QE2 for a voyage ‘down under’ to New Zealand and Australia. He explores Rotorua and its geothermal world of mudpots, geysers and steaming lakes and cliffs, the Tasman Galcier in a ski plane , as well as visiting Auckland, Wellington, Christchurch and Queenstown. In Australia the Sydney Opera House is visited, as is a sheep station while shearing is underway. A behind the scenes look is taken at life aboard the ship from the bridge and the engine control centre to the largest floating kitchens in the world.

results.title: Queen (A Portrait of Madonna)
results.brief_description: What happens when 30 Madonna fans sing the iconic artist’s entire ‘Immaculate Collection’ album a capella?

constellations_other.name: Voice and the moving image
constellations_other.description: Sound changed cinema, but it wasn't always welcome, but it hasn't stopped people aspiring for the spotlight.

results.description:
What happens when 30 Madonna fans sing the iconic artist’s entire ‘Immaculate Collection’ album a capella?

The magic of ‘Queen’ lies in the way the individual voices of 30 strangers combine to create an otherworldly choir in songs like ‘Vogue’ and ‘Cherish,’ suggesting that we are all truly greater than the sum of our parts.

Each amateur performer reveals a heartfelt, emotional connection to Madonna’s lyrics, rhythms, melodies and harmonies. Through song, the fans in each isolated video screen merge into a symbiotic whole, implying that the boundaries which divide us are ultimately porous and illusory.
